reviewText: (4 1/2 *'s) `The Bourne Ultimatum' is a non-stop thriller ride that easily propels itself to the top of 2007's three-peat super summer.  The third in the series, Jason Bourne (played superbly by a tough and tormented Matt Damon) still suffers his same identity crisis, this time criss-crossing his way across the globe with breakneck speed.  Suspenseful for more than the thrill of the chase, we are given a gripping sense of drama as CIA director, Noah Vosen (played with tough officiousness by David Strathairn in another great performance) and his sparring co-leader, Pamela Landy (Joan Allen in an admirably complex role) come to grips with Bourne and his alleged treason against their assassination operation. Hooking up with a fellow operative Nicky Parsons (a sleight-of-hand Julia Stiles), Bourne and associates provide enough development to keep us guessing throughout.Besides all of the identity intrigue, the action is relentless without being predictable.  All the scenes of chase and violence are fresh and invigorating.  Flashbacks from Jason's fragmented memory add substance to the fray, and the board room tension at control central, both at the CIA and the UK are formidable.  Creeping into his memory at various times, senior CIA figure, Dr. Albert Hirsch (in a welcome sunset role by Albert Finney), gives the mystery proper credence.  While I found Greengrass's direction a mastery of timing, drama, and movement, I do have a quibble with the editing.  Although an acquired taste, too many scenes are presented as an enhanced blur, both in the thick of the chase and with the flashback sequences.  Just as an observation, the revelations presented are satisfying with the resolution of his identity being one of the least compelling.`The Bourne Ultimatum' deserves approximately the same accolades as 'Casino Royale (2-Disc Full Screen Edition)' with its stunning development, pace, and execution.  For those who love action pictures, this film is a list-topping must-see movie.
summary: Where in the World is Jason Bourne?

reviewText: The Bourne Ultimatum is an incredible achievement, but particularly more so because it is the third movie in what is promising to be one of the most exhilarating movie franchises in cinema history. The movie is intense, suspenseful, and extremely dynamic. It grabs your attention and holds on tight all the way until the credits.The music score, as does the rest of the movie, hits the right tone and all the right notes in all the right places.Matt Damon (The Good Shepherd, Good Will Hunting) proves he is still on top of his game and Julia Stiles (Save the Last Dance, 10 Things I Hate About You) gets a bit more of a script to work with than she's had in the predecessors. Her appearance in the beginning of the movie is extremely welcome (Sidenote: her actual appearance is totally cool, particularly, the haircut with the highlights suits her face marvelously). Joan Allen (The Contender, Pleasantville) mouthes off against David Strathairn (We Are Marshall, Good Night, and Good Luck) quite nicely as well.Just when you think there haven't been enough explosions in this thriller, the movie impresses you with what has become signature car chases for The Bourne trilogy. In fact, I would go as far as to say that the stuntwork that was designed into it is a lot cooler than the let's-bomb-the-entire-bridge sequence in the only other successful sequel of Summer 2007, Live Free or Die Hard. The choreography of the chase scenes and the fighting scenes is also commendable. The fighting between Jason Bourne and Dash, another "asset," is an incredibly skillful stunt scene with raw energy seldom shown on screen.This action-packed thriller is as intelligent as it is entertaining. Rising above the standard popcorn fare, the movie also makes subtle and not so subtle commentary on political policy, from rendition to CIA agent training, and lightly focuses on the argument of when the end justifies the means.The Bourne Ultimatum proves that sequels aren't necessary an easy way for the studios to earn the big bucks and something for the movie watchers to avoid. And as a sequel this movie manages something that is extremely rare in this era of sequel-driven Hollywood - The Bourne Ultimatum manages to top its predecessors. And, for that, if nothing else, this movie must be watched and celebrated.
summary: Bourne Series Proves That Three Trumps Two

reviewText: 2007 was a year filled to the brim with trilogies coming to their end, and while some proved disappointing there is one that stands towering above the rest as pure excellence.  Yes, I am talking about `The Bourne Ultimatum', a film that can rightfully be considered one of the best films of this year.  It's breathtaking, heart pounding excitement that is, get this, smart.  The first two Bourne films were amazing as well, but this third installment is notches above the rest.  So, if you've been let down by the bigger, showier trilogies that were wrapped up this year (namely that Spider Mess) then `The Bourne Ultimatum' may just be the cure for that undeniable itch.Picking up where `The Bourne Supremacy' left off, and subsequently where `The Bourne Identity' left off as well, `The Bourne Ultimatum' throws us in the heat of the chase with our hero Jason Bourne being pursued in Moscow.  Bourne is still tracking down the people responsible for his condition (not to mention the death of his girlfriend) and they are in the same respect hunting him down as well, in order to tie up lose ends.  Heading the man hunt is CIA Deputy Director Noah Vosen, a man determined to kill Bourne and any who aid in his pursuit.  As Jason comes closer to learning the truth about his identity he is helped along by Pamela Landy and Nicky Parsons, two people who have seen the corruptness surrounding the pursuit of Jason Bourne and have made the decision to help Bourne expose it.Taking the reigns once again is Oscar nominated director Paul Greengrass.  Greengrass has perfected his execution of Bourne, relying heavy on fast-cut editing and scene splicing to create an effect of standing right beside Jason Bourne as he races atop buildings, tears up gravel or pummels the enemy.  There are moments within `The Bourne Ultimatum' that could literally stop your heart with its pure intensity.  A scene where Bourne is racing to find Nicky before an assassin does is one of those scenes, so intense that I literally found myself refusing to blink.The action sequences are out of this world, eye popping spectacles that will keep the viewer entranced until they are through only to quickly throw you into yet another heart racing scene.Matt Damon has been one of those actors who I never really got.  He was impressive in `Good Will Hunting' but nothing mind blowing, and then he was mind blowing in `The Talented Mr. Ripley' but aside from that he never really made an impact on me, at least not a lasting one.  I was ready to write him off as a one of those actors who lucked into a good role and then he did `The Bourne Identity' and I thought to myself, `maybe this is his calling', and then `The Bourne Supremacy' made me believe that thought and now `The Bourne Ultimatum' makes me invest much faith in the fact that Damon is much more than a lucky actor.  I just hope his future roles reflect that.  As Jason Bourne Damon did what many actors try to and so few succeed and that is to make an action movie hero a real and identifiable human being.I was very happy to see Julia Stiles get more to do here.  I often wonder what happened to her career.  Back in 2000 she was the new face, the new star who was supposed to blow up big and then she kind of disappeared and all the roles that should have gone her way went the way of everyone else.  She's appeared in each and every Bourne film with little or nothing to do but her character is finally given some breathing room here and she does as much as she can with it proving once again that she needs to get bigger and better roles.  Joan Allen is always a delight, and she proves to be memorable here as well, but the scene stealer to me this go around is David Strathairn.  He just sinks his teeth into his role, indulging himself in the very despicability of his character.  I expected more out of Albert Finney and must admit I was a little disappointed with his performance when his character was finally unveiled, but that I think had more to do with the script which didn't really give him much to do.  I must admit too that seeing Paddy Considine show up in the beginning moments of the film was such a delight.`The Bourne Ultimatum' is one of those films that grabs your attention and never lets you go.  If forces you to use your brain as much as your eyes and that's commendable because it's the type of film that could have easily relied on the action scene and  the fight scenes and the magnetism of it's stars to haul in it's audience but it doesn't rest on those sturdy shoulders alone.  No, like I said earlier, this movie is smart.`The Bourne Ultimatum' may very well be one of the best films of the year.  It's already landed on quite a few top ten list, not the least of which was the NBR's announced the beginning of the month.  Will it make my top ten?  Maybe.  It's certainly in the running.  It made me weak with pure excitement from beginning to end and any film that can successfully pull that off deserves my nod of approval.  If you're looking for an all around crowd pleasing good time then look no further than `The Bourne Ultimatum'.
summary: One masterfully effective way to end a trilogy...

reviewText: As I watched THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM I kept thinking to myself, "Haven't I seen this before?" and then I realized I essentially had but it was done better in THE BOURNE SUPREMECY. reviewText: I think the third chapter of the Bourne films is best, but to explain why, something needs to be said for the comparatively different directorial styles that occur between "The Bourne Identity" (with Doug Liman) and "Supremacy" and "Ultimatum" (with Paul Greengrass).  Much has been made of Greengrass' "shaky" and "MTV-style" quick-cut editing.  Doug Liman favors a far more expository style of filming; he will use a tripod, and when a hand held camera is in play he still makes everything visible.  This tactic allows the more virtuoso fight sequences with a high level of artistry to be most pleasing to viewers.  For an example, watch the apartment fight in Paris in "The Bourne Identity."  Every single punch, block, and kick is visible to the viewers--and it's awesome.  We delight in the choreography and skill, and thank the director for showing us everything.  The negative of this style is that more visceral moments (i.e. car chases, sudden impacts, etc.) are less immediate.  As viewers who are safe to see everything, we don't necessarily feel like we are part of that action.  For an example of this, watch the car chase scene in "The Bourne Identity."  While entertaining and even creative with the drive down the stairwell, it lacks punch, and we don't feel like we're fully "there."  This is where Greengrass comes in.  His use with handheld cameras makes us feel the chaos and immediacy that tripods shy away from.  Watch the car chase from "Supremacy."  Every impact is brutal, the moments sudden, the feeling of being trapped complete.  Or consider the way Spielberg used it in "Saving Private Ryan."  Would the storming of the beach in Normandy be as effective if the handhelds weren't used to make us feel completely there and part of the action?  Now, I'm not saying Greengrass is Spielberg.  In "Supremacy," I thought he went much too far with the handhelds and made the centerpiece fight scene borderline unwatchable.  All I saw were flayling limbs, and all I heard were grunts and the sounds of punches.  All in all, I left the theatre dissapointed.  I thought Greengrass had done a great job using the handhelds in scenes of dialogue and in the final car chase, but that all the hand-to-hand combat which I had loved in the first film had been brutally skewed.  Now, Greengrass is back for "Ultimatum."  When I heard this, I was very worried.  However, halfway through the movie, I realized I was in the hands of a director who had kept everything good from "Supremacy" and improved upon it's faults threefold.  This doesn't mean you will see each fight scene with the clarity of Doug Liman.  But what will happen is that you will feel the immediacy AND be able to appreciate the choreography at the same time.  This doesn't mean Greengrass has used less handheld camera work.  It some cases, it's more frenetic because there is more action and more chases.  But I firmly believe that he has fixed what was broken in Supremacy.  In each fight scene, I was finally able to follow what was going on and revel in the virtuosity of the action, and on top of that, the handheld cameras made me feel like I was absoutely there.  Is the centerpiece fight in Tangier as good or better than the one in Paris from "Bourne Identity?"  I'd have to see the movie again to be sure, but my first instinct (while openly chuckling with enjoyment) was yes.  It was brutal, visceral, and completely watchable.  That's pretty much how all of "Ultimatum" is, with the addition of being well-acted, smart, and the best action movie of the year.

reviewText: Not being much of a Matt Damon fan, I rarely look forward to any of his films. There are exceptions, of course, most notably his surprisingly great performance inThe Good Shepherd. But even within The Good Shepherd, Damon's emotional range isn't challenged, which is why the part was perfect for him considering who he was portraying.Part of that issue spills over into this series where we see a super-spy with little-to-no emotions that might help audiences "feel" anything for Jason Bourne. But THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM and its predecessors aren't about character, they're about action, and director Greengrass knows action very well. If you think these stories have ANYTHING to do with character, you are seriously deluded. We never understand the motivations behind any of the prime or secondary characters. This is glaringly obvious when Jason and a CIA "asset" sent out to eliminate him battle and, eventually, come to some sort of understanding.But, like I said, these stories aren't character pieces but adrenaline pumping action sequences designed as a thrill ride. And on that level expectations are well-met.Running from city to city, this is basically one long chase scene where the CIA learns that Bourne has resurfaced and several key officers within "The Agency" don't want him to discover a covert operation that harkens back to Bourne's uber-secret beginnings.David Strathairn (Good Night, and Good Luck) and Scott Glenn (Freedom Writers) star as two powerful but ultimately despicable Agency higher-ups who's attempts to snare Jason Bourne are continually foiled by Bourne and someone within their own department.Female leads Joan Allen (The Ice Storm) and Julia Stiles (The Omen, 2006) pull in okay performances; Allen as the sympathetic CIA agent who wants to know why her superiors are so enamored with killing off Jason Bourne, and Stiles as the former love interest who reemerges to initially help Jason but only puts herself in danger and must be saved by Bourne. Although that was a bit confusing (i.e., their relationship history), the rooftop chase through Tangier is flat-out amazing.This is one of those film series' where you need to be in the mood for such things. If you want thoughtful, look elsewhere. But if you want heart-pounding action, you're in for a treat.

Also, more with Simon Ross and we also see how Bourne found out about him."Man on the Move: Jason Bourne" takes us through several of the countries that Bourne visits during the course of the film. He says that he wanted to set a high tempo right from the first frame because that is what these films are all about. reviewText: The consensus opinion of this movie is that it is an excellent action film, and in the main I think this is very true--with two caveats.  1) The "Bourne Identity" grounded its story and action with a sense of real human beings caught up in a growing crisis: Damon's Bourne and Franka Potente's Marie.  The action slows down, they talk, they grow together, we--more and more--care about them.  This adds a vital dimension to the exciting action scenes.  Paul Greengrass directs the two sequels, and sacrifices the human dimension for simply more action, faster action, hyped up action.  You can only go so far in this direction without snapping all credibility, and moving into the realm of the unintended comic.  Matt Damon is very good in the first movie, but he could almost be replaced in the sequels with a computer graphic, as his acting ability, and ability to convey an inner dimension, is so little used (we only care about him at all because our sense of him is carried over from Doug Liman's first film).2)  Many viewers have complained about the use of the "Shakey Cam" in the Greengrass sequels (particularly in "Ultimatum,"), but this is not really identifying the problem.  The camera does move almost all the time in "Ultimatum," and frequently vibrates, oscillates, jiggles as it moves, etc.  But this would be ok--and sometimes even exciting--if the audience could nevertheless see what is going on: the total arc of a given action, with an environmental context clearly established and maintained throughout the action.  This is what we need to see and instinctively follow if our empathetic involvement is to be fully engaged.  It is dramatic action--human action- -that is exciting, not the action of the camera recording the human action.  And it is not the "shakiness" that is the primary problem, but the hyper cutting that goes on within a scene, so that we lose context and perspective, and are given instead vast fast flurries of hyper-kinetic fragments of scenes that are machine-gunned at us throughout almost all the entire film.But even with what I think are these significant flaws, the film does generate lots of excitement and a real sense of the continuation of a kind of urgent, mythic journey.  I think it is a good movie that would have been brilliant if only we could be involved more in it, and see more of it!

reviewText: The summer of 2007 finally granted fans of the action genre a worthwhile reason to return to theaters with the release of The Bourne Ultimatum.  This final chapter in the trilogy picks up five years after the last installment left off, with an injured Jason Bourne (Matt Damon) being brought back into the CIA under the assumption that he is the mole who leaked information about the Black Briar upgrade.  The story is simple in plot and not unlike that of the first two films: an ordinary guy who has been thrown into extraordinary circumstances struggles to find out who he really is and what made him do the things he has done.  With Paul Greengrass returning to the Director's Chair, though, the emphasis is not on the proverbial quest to find one's true identity but on the literal chase, as Bourne races both time and the government to get his answers, and that is where this film takes the action genre to a whole new level.Greengrass is notorious for using tight close-ups and jerky hand-held camera work to create a frenetic energy about his films, and The Bourne Ultimatum utilizes that style to its advantage in every frame.  The camera doesn't merely record each of the three vehicle chase scenes or hand-to-hand combat scenes; it is part of the choreography and a character in and of itself.  The camera draws the audience in actively, you are not merely watching something play out in front of you, but you are right there, experiencing everything with the same intensity.  Perhaps this is most notably evident when Bourne jumps across the rooftop, crashing through a closed window in Madrid, because the camera stays so closely over his shoulder that it feels like you're right there behind him taking those same leaps.Greengrass also uses camera movement to enhance his tone of paranoia, confusion, and ambiguity of right and wrong, as well.  Bourne is a victim as someone who has had his past stolen from him, but he is not innocent, either, as he has succumbed to acts of vengeance and killed many along the way.  When he sits staring at his bloody hands, the camera sways subtly, but when the image switches to the CIA chief at his desk, discussing acts of vengeance in the name of national security, the camera movement picks up, blurring the background-- in which is a well-placed American flag-- so focus is pulled to his face and the hypocrisy spewing from his mouth.  On the surface, The Bourne Ultimatum centers on frantic manhunt featuring tons of bullets, but if you take a closer look, you can actually find a deeper message behind all of the violence.There are five "Making Of" featurettes on The Bourne Ultimatum DVD, all of which focus on the action sequences, rather than interviews with the actors discussing their respective characters' arcs throughout the trilogy.  For a film that relies on an extremely fast pace to keep the audience's adrenaline up, equally energetic Special Features only serve to enhance that tone.  One of said featurettes is solely dedicated to the aforementioned rooftop pursuit, creating a star out of Dan Bradley, the Bourne Stunt Coordinator.  Bradley is responsible for any and all sequences in which something flies through the air-- even if it's just an actor jumping-- and the seamless integration of his team with Greengrass' direction of the actors is what makes The Bourne Ultimatum such a successful film.  It's nice to finally give credit where it's due and honor at least one of the lesser-known players in the action genre."Man on the Move" looks at the complexity but also the beauty of shooting at various "real" (no studio soundstages here!) overseas locations, lingering on London, Madrid, and Tangier.  It is especially interesting to learn some of the more "guerilla" tactics these union crewmembers had to adopt just due to shooting around real patrons and city passersby.  Along the same lines, "New York Chase" showcases the long, expensive finale stunt sequence and how it was able to come about in such a busy, working city.  Blips on the radar are "Planning The Punches," a quick (five minute) look at the subtle dance of the fight scene between Bourne and Desh (Joey Ansah), and "Driving School," which is pretty much just a couple of minutes of Damon having fun on a driving course.There are five deleted scenes on the DVD, as well, some of which are really just extended scenes, but all of which further prove the smart choices Greengrass made when working with Editor Christopher Rouse in leaving these bits out of the actual final cut.  One includes a subplot about Pamela Landy (Joan Allen) losing her job that would have slowed the pacing of the film significantly.  At first glance, the audio commentary feels like an afterthought, as Greengrass is the only one appearing on the track, but he fills the gaps nicely, offering humorous anecdotes from production.The HD version of the DVD release comes with additional extra features, including a picture-in-picture function (presumably to watch one of the behind-the-scenes featurettes while keeping the actual film itself on in the background), which is a ridiculous way to watch a film that deserves your complete attention.  There is also an interactive Spy Training Game that is a great way to occupy a child you think might not be old enough to watch the actual film.
summary: Making A Solid Case For The Best Of The Series

reviewText: Sequels often run out of ideas and lose the freshness that made the original films so appealing. The Bourne Ultimatum, the third film in a triptych that began in 2002 with The Bourne Identity, bucks sequel redundancy. With the ultra-focused Matt Damon returning as renegade CIA assassin Jason Bourne, the film is an irresistible rush of action and suspense.Effectively building upon the familiar Bourne character, The Bourne Ultimatum borrows real-world news and expands it into an explosive story about a deep-cover CIA program led by one of the summer's great movie villains.David Strathairn, the recipient of an Oscar nomination for his portrayal of courageous newsman Edward R. Murrow in Good Night, and Good Luck, turns to the dark side as the arrogant and amoral boss of a CIA operation dubbed Blackbriar. He's definitely a bad guy who inspires thoughts of revenge.Despite The Bourne Ultimatum's political backdrop, the film is first of all a great action flick. Except for some rare moments of quiet, the action is constant and furiously visceral. The film's three-way battle consists of the CIA vs. Bourne and Bourne vs. both the CIA-sanctioned assassins (euphemistically dubbed assets) and the people pulling the killers' strings.A whistleblower tells a reporter for The Guardian newspaper (Paddy Considine) about Blackbriar, the blackest of the CIA's black-ops programs. Because Bourne, who's still wondering about his identity, wants to know what the reporter knows, he makes contact. A mere reporter, however, is no match for assassins who answer only to Strathairn's deep-cover operation.British director Paul Greengrass masterfully employs the streets of London and its Waterloo tube station as the public-filled set for one of the film's marathon chase and stalking scenes. Here and elsewhere, and without turning heavy-handed about it, the film reveals in bold print that innocent human beings are being hunted.The international action moves to crowded Tangier in Morocco, the site for another virtuosic action sequence involving local policemen, hundreds of extras and auto traffic. In the intimate setting of an empty Moroccan apartment, too, there's an amazingly violent confrontation between Bourne and his unyielding pursuer.All the while, director Greengrass (United 93, The Bourne Supremacy) turns the tension high. The jeopardy that returning cast member Julia Stiles finds herself in, for instance, rises to Hitchcockian proportions.One of America's great actresses, Joan Allen, also returns to the series. Allen doesn't have much to do as Pamela Landy, CIA internal investigator, but she makes the best of it and her character is crucial to the plot.The Bourne Ultimatum shows that a hellacious action movie need not be mindless and only about action, fights and stunts. It's an attention commanding, satisfying grand finale for the Bourne trilogy.

reviewText: No matter what criticisms I have read regarding the choice of Matt Damon to play Robert Ludlum's amnesiac covert agent in the Jason Bourne trilogy, this particular installment, "The Bourne Ultimatum," the third of three films based on this character's search for his own brain-washed identity, proves that Damon fills the bill with an assured and serious super-spy air that has little to do with the likes of James Bond.  Damon exudes quiet get-the-business-done confidence that entertains and at the same time jolts the viewer with enough pent-up horsepower to land him on Mars without ever realizing that the rocket was entered and took off two hours earlier.With little dialogue, the film rushes from one explosive chase scene to another. Bourne propels himself from one world capital to another with surprising intimate knowledge of each setting.  A blur of streets in Moscow, Tangiers, Paris, London, Turin and of course, New York, the scene of Treadstone's diabolical beginnings mesmerize the viewer in a whirlwind of events seen from behind the scenes by CIA personnel intent to blindly protect the integrity of an organization that has little regard for its own failings. Amazing camera action actually simulates the feeling of being in the middle of all those fantastically executed martial arts chops and blocks from the alternating perspective of Bourne and his sparring antagonists.  With all this extra-strength action, character development is minimal; some disclosures involving repeat characters suggest another installment will ensue to follow-up on loose ends that further deploy Bourne as the ultimate weapon and super competent operative---perhaps the recent offerings by novelist Eric Von Lustbader ---The Bourne Legacy and The Bourne Betrayal will serve as fodder for this extremely exciting and lucrative series.Director Greengrass does this one right tinting his film with an urban grit quality that dictates the no-nonsense momentum the high-speed plot and Bourne's shaky memories from the past utilize to spiral into a labyrinth of familiar but fresh intrigue that we already know Bourne can handle all too well.Bottom line:  "The Bourne Ultimatum" threads together one chase and fight scene after another.  As formulaic as this may sound, there is nothing boring or blasé about this last film in the trilogy created by Robert Ludlum.  Indeed under Greengrass's direction, uber-agent Matt Damon catapults right out of the tinsel town world of nebulous spies into a fully realized real world of espionage that pulls the audience in from the get-go.  Recommended.Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"

reviewText: "The Bourne Ultimatum" (2007) is a fun, well-crafted action thriller, the third installment in the Jason Bourne spy saga.  Once again, Matt Damon excels as an amnesiac, government-manufactured super-assassin -- his performance is in many ways minimalistic, but the minute responses and micro-expressions that pass across his face speak volumes.  The film is fast-paced and consistently enthralling, with highly stylized editing and cinematography that help put a new look on some now-familiar situations in the spy-thriller genre.  There are chase scenes, and hide-in-a-crowd shenanigans, control-room screen-watching and lots of well-placed, unnerving cell phone calls, but it is the fragmentary visual presentation that gives this film its unique feel, and that keeps the audience as off-balance as Bourne's pursuers.Minutes after you finish watching this film, after you catch your breath, you'll realize that the plot was pretty flimsy -- although the assassins that are sent after Bourne are refreshingly lethal and efficient, David Strathairn's big bad-guy, CIA Deputy Director character folds like a deck of cards in the end, and Bourne's psychological revelation when he gets his memory back is kind of anticlimactic. But the action's the star here, and the brutal duel between Bourne and a rival agent named Desh is one of the most tautly choreographed, lethal fight scenes in modern cinema history.  So, are we ready for Bourne 4?  Heck, yeah.  Bring it on!  (Joe Sixpack, Slipcue film reviews)

reviewText: I enjoy movies that are nonstop obstacle courses; in that respect, THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM does not disappoint.  This third installment of the Bourne franchise features grim-faced Matt Damon as a former CIA hit man with no identity--but an unwavering determination to whip out a can of payback. reviewText: The third, and alas, the final installment of the Bourne series has landed, and what a landing it was.  The strongest of the three installments (the first two being excellent in their own right) propels the viewer through almost non-stop, high-tense action, leaving the audience on the edge of their seats.  For those who have missed either of the first two motion pictures ... and shame on you if you did;), it's a must to see at least the second installment (The Bourne Supremacy) in order not to get totally lost in this one.  Do yourself a favor and see both fine films (The Bourne Identity and The Bourne Supremacy) before seeing The Bourne Ultimatum.As with the other two films, The Bourne Ultimatum was shot at several different exotic locals (a trademark of this series).  "Ultimatum" starts where "Supremacy" left off.  Actually, it sort of spans The Bourne Supremacy, telling us what transpired at the end of that 2nd installment that we did not see.Now, when I mean non-stop action, that doesn't mean it's the entire picture.  The story of Bourne's identity and his role in "Treadstone" (a CIA Black-Ops program) comes full circle and the scenes inside the CIA (especially the Pamela Landy character, played wonderfully by Joan Allen) are as intense as they are interesting.  More important still, nothing is telegraphed in the entire series.  We don't know what is going to happen, all the way to (and including) the end.  Also, the character Nicky Parsons (played nicely by Julia Stiles) is expanded in the third episode, adding another interesting branch to the Bourne saga.And one cannot (or should not) underrate the performance of Matt Damon in yet another demanding Bourne role.  While he puts the "E" in exciting fight sequences, he also puts the "I" in intelligence.  His character is thinking every second of every day and has a purpose in everything he does (which is not always known by the audience at the time).  Damon brings this out (often subtly) in each film, making Bourne the super-agent of super-agents, but never in an unbelievable or plastic (James Bond) type of way (not to say the Bond series wasn't good at times, but Bond is pretty light fare -- almost comic book in depth -- compared to the Bourne series).This is a hard-hitting series, intelligently written and wonderfully acted and directed.  And as had been said by many people, many times, this is exactly what a secret agent movie should be (and very rarely is).  The only problem I have with this series is the over-use of the hand-held camera technique.  While not as jerky or blurry as the second episode, it can still be distracting at times.  However, the use of the hand-held camera tends to put the audience in the middle of everything, giving it that extra intensity and realism not found in most films.  And believe me, you will be right in the middle of the action in this brilliant installment ... and at times, amazingly so.  This is one heck of a series and one heck of a movie.Because this film essentially completes the trilogy, and I feel it is the strongest of the series (part 1 being very good, part 2 even better, while part 3 the best), I rate this installment the highest of the three.  Between 1 and 10, I feel The Bourne Ultimatum deserves a solid 9.Sadly, I think this is the logical end to this series, and for that I am somewhat bummed that we won't see another installment.  But hey, this is Hollywood where ANYTHING can happen.  I can only hope if Hollywood reprises the Bourne role (and Hollywood is quite renown for doing this), they don't muck it up, and will maintain the integrity and excitement of the other three films.  And no, I don't want anyone but Matt Damon playing the lead role, nor anyone but Paul Greengrass directing it.

reviewText: In "The Bourne Ultimatum", the third installment of the Jason Bourne saga, all the familar and welcome elements of the earlier movies are present.  The action is non-stop.  Several sequences are shot in a grainy, off-angle, often under-lighted manner that adds to the suspense.  The locations (Moscow, London, Turin, and New York) are exotic battlegrounds for close combat, gunfights, and violent car chases.Matt Damon is simply superb in his by-now glove fit as conflicted and amnesiac CIA assassin Jason Bourne, relentlessly on the move and endlessly innovative.  Julia Stiles returns as CIA logistician Nicki Parsons, and Joan Allen does another turn as Pam Landy, a hard-nosed agency staffer with a surprising amount of sympathy for the killing machine her organization loosed on the world.The action picks up right where the Bourne Supremacy left off, with a injured Bourne evading police in Moscow.  He breaks into a clinic to treat his wound; the pain and stress trigger a flashback of his indoctrination as an agent.  The story fast-forwards to a British journalist in Italy and London seeking information about a covert operation code-named BLACKFRIAR.  The journalist draws the attention of both the CIA and Jason Bourne; the CIA to seal a potential leak and Bourne to seek clues to his identity.  Bourne will reach the journalist first but lose him to BLACKFRIAR itself, a no-holds barred counter-terrorism operation run well outside existing intelligence law by a posturing and cynical Deputy Director played by David Straitharn.With few new elements to introduce, Director Paul Greengrass wisely keeps the action moving at a breathless pace, much faster than the viewer can note or worry over plot holes.  Bourne relentlessly follows an unbroken string of clues through a small army of CIA operatives and a couple of Bourne-like skilled killers back to his point of origin.  Along the way, he will form surprising alliances with several CIA personnel uncomfortable with the extra-judicial killing of BLACKFRIARS.  We glimpse Bourne's long-suppressed humanity in his interaction with a sympathetic Nicki Parsons and with one of his own clones.  The ending nicely wraps the storyline of the current movie, but leaves the door open for sequels.This movie is highly recommended as exciting entertainment, loosely based on the Robert Ludlum book of the same name.

reviewText: As director Paul Greengrass proved withUnited 93last year, he has an uncanny ability to tap into something viscerally powerful with his films. His extensive background in documentary filmmaking really comes to the fore when it comes to the ultra-lean storytelling, propulsive pacing and superbly rendered action sequences in this genuinely suspenseful 2007 film. Densely conceived plot turns are swift and sometimes contrived enough for eye-rolling, but Greengrass knows how to keep a viewer enraptured with his pure cinematic technique. As the third and presumably final entry in the Bourne series, which update Robert Ludlum's nail-biting novels from post-Vietnam War to the far more ambiguous post-9/11 era, this one picks up immediately where 2004'sThe Bourne Supremacyleft off with CIA assassin Jason Bourne still struggling to recollect his past as he dismantles conspiracies emanating from the senior operatives within the agency.Bourne has become the CIA's most-wanted. Regardless, despite a number of cunning assassins on his trail, he is intent on finding out who he is amid muddled flashbacks of mysterious interrogations. He gets help from fellow CIA agent Nicky Parsons, his former Paris contact, in Madrid where they end up in a diabolical chase through the alleys and rooftops of Tangiers. Both returning fromSupremacy, Christopher Rouse's kinetic editing and Oliver Wood's hand-held camerawork make a powerful impact on this scene by making the action feel compellingly claustrophobic. The action all works toward a head-turning series of twists that bring Bourne closer to his real identity. The elaborately constructed screenplay is credited to three writers - Tony Gilroy, Scott Z. Burns and George Nolfi - who know how to play off our own paranoia about security and U.S. intelligence. Playwright Tom Stoppard apparently also had a hand in the final script. A sharp, Grade-A cast has been assembled, though this movie is obviously not an actor's showcase. Matt Damon returns as Bourne, all cool physicality with enough non-ironic humanity to allow us a rooting interest in his fate.Bringing her natural authority to the role, Joan Allen also makes an effortless return as Deputy CIS Director Pamela Landy. Her philosophical adversary at the agency is the Machiavellian CIA official Noah Vosen played with surprising relish by the usually low-key David Straithairn. Paddy Considine makes the most of his few scenes as the understandably confused Ross, while an avuncular Albert Finney shows up late in the film with menacing subtlety as the key to Bourne's memory. The one weak link continues to be Julia Stiles, who maintains her poker-faced petulance as Parsons from the previous films and remains only marginally interesting as Bourne's female foil by default in this go-around. However, it's really Greengrass' craftsmanship that shines brightest here. A perfect example can be seen in the extended breathtaking chase sequence with a British journalist Simon Ross being tracked through London's particularly busy Waterloo Station for a planned rendezvous with Bourne. If there is one drawback to the third film, it is the presumption of some understanding of what happened in the first two installments. It just makes some of the set-up a little harder to follow. Otherwise, this is bracing, often enthralling entertainment for anyone who loves this genre of cinema.
summary: Breathless, Suspenseful Action Really Shows Greengrass' Mastery of this Genre

reviewText: After the first two stunning Bourne instalments everyone wanted to know if the conclusion would be just as good.  Well it has surpassed my expectations and once again pushed the bar much higher in this genre.  Right from the start the pace is fast, as though you are carrying on watching the second film.The one criticism I have of the early part is the meeting at Langley between Pamela Landy and CIA Director Ezra Kramer discussing Jason Bourne.  Considering what happens later on in this film I felt that this should have been much more edgier.  I would have expected Kramer to put Landy on the back foot over Bourne and making it clear that she hadn't covered herself with glory over the affair. That would have made  Landy later in the film being shipped off to CIA Deputy Director Noah Vosen's shady operations much more understandable.  Similarly the DVD deleted scenes includes one where Kramer appears before a Senate Select Committee and this really should have been in the film to set out Kramer's character more fully.The confrontations Jason Bourne becomes involved with in this film are powerful though.  You get to understand just how good he is and why the CIA absolutely fear this man.  The Treadstone operation put every effort into the development of this asset and their constant nightmare was Bourne on the loose.  Men and women in the CIA who would normally take the tightest situations in their stride suffer uncharacteristic failures when Bourne's rampaging around the world.My favourite parts of this movie are the fight between Jason Bourne and Desh Bouksani, absolutely stunning.  The speed of these two is breathtaking and by the end you too will be breathless.  Also Jason Bournes distraction machinations against Vosen in New York is wonderful and inspired.  I know some feel that Paul Greengrass' in your face action scenes are overdone, but you really do feel that you're right there in the middle of the action and he has perfected this feeling for the viewer in Ultimatum.  Whereas the car chase in Moscow during Supremacy was too long and overdone, things are kept shorter and much better in Ultimatum.Is there room for more Bourne?  Absolutely! Don't take any notice of those who say that this ties things up nicely and the franchise should be left alone.  Bourne is hot property and he will be back.  The situation surrounding Nicky Parsons is still very much unresolved.  What is it that Jason Bourne doesn't remember?  Has everything rotten in the CIA been resolved now?  I very much doubt that.  I feel that the whole Treadstone/Blackbriar programme runs even deeper and the conspiracy could go much higher.  Has Pamela Landy now crossed those in very high places?  Will there be repercussions for all concerned? We shall see...I am really pleased with the DVD.  For once most of the deleted scenes, many of which seem to very out of place to the actual cut, don't leave you feeling that they should have been included.  There's a whole long list of features and if you are getting this for the holiday then you will be able to sit back and allow yourself to become completely immersed in the bonus features.Overall The Bourne Ultimatum is an outstanding film and this is a very pleasing DVD.  Following the release of The Bourne Supremacy other film makers in the action genre realised that they had to raise their game in the post Bourne movie world.  Now with the release of The Bourne Ultimatum those same movie makers must be scratching their heads and wondering if they can really compete in this Bourne again genre!

reviewText: The third movie in the series of the CIA amnesiac super agent, Jason Bourne (Matt Damon) is as dynamic, fast-moving, filled with the first class chase sequences, and never-stopping tension as the first two movies. All three movies make a very exiting trilogy and also manage to tell something mportant on the subject of the honorable goals that not always justify the means. This time, Jason Bourne is set to find out how, when, and where it all started for him. He wants to remember all, he wants to know what the flashbacks that keep coming back mean and by doing so, he once again becomes a danger to CIA. The agency made him a part of a special top-secret program "Blackbriar" which had created a perfect killing machine, a super assassin out of him. Now, he presents an imminent danger for CIA's director Ezra Kramer (Scott Glenn) who had approved the program and for Noah Vosen (David Strathairn, excellent as usual), the chief of department's division of top secret operations. Vosen does not hate Bourne personally. He knows that Bourne is as a treat for the agency and has to be eliminated and he would use all possible high-tech devices and techniques as well as ruthless manipulation to trace him and to see him dead. Bourne also has allies inside CIA, Pamela Landy (Joan Allen) and Nicky Parsons (grown up Julia Stiles has just a few words in the script but the close ups of her face that changed emotions and feelings so vividly made her character compelling and memorable.)A lot has been said about Paul Greengrass's ("United 93," "Bourne Supremacy") directing and his use of fast cuts and an unsteady camera. I found his approach competent, appropriate and fully justified. In the film packed with suspense and thrills, at least two chase scenes are perfect and breathtaking. The long scene in London Waterloo station where Bourne tries to make a contact with a reporter for The Guardian, Simon Ross (Paddy Considine) is a masterwork. Bourne knows that Ross has been watched by the CIA high-tech specialists in NYC office and has been followed by the operatives at the station while an excellent sniper is waiting somewhere for a signal to terminate the reporter. Bourne controls the situation by trying to get the information from Ross and to protect him. Another scene takes place in Tangier as Bourne attempts to talk to a man from his flashbacks who has knowledge of his past before he ever became Jason Bourne. Bringing the action to Tangier, reminds me the old movie "Pepe Le Moko" (1937) directed by Julien Duvivier where the main character stuck forever in the suffocating maze of narrow streets of Tangier. It also made me think that Bourne movies are not just high adrenalin thrillers/mystery/spy flicks but they are first of all about longing for home, the quest for returning to the roots, searching for and understanding one's real identity and as such they are more interesting, deeper, and poignant than just a well done action flick. Maybe the movies would not have made me think so had another actor played Jason Bourne. Matt Damon, the actor with a lot of charisma and high intelligence is perfect for a role of a thinking superman that wants to know who and what is behind his super abilities.4.5/5 or 9/10

reviewText: Jason Bourne is still running, and so is the Bourne series with this third entry, which carries on some of the plot and characters from the previous two episodes.  Bourne is still trying to discover his past, but now he must also decide about his future, and the kind of person he wants to be.  But some of the people behind the original Treadstone don't want Bourne to uncover the dark secrets that lie behind his entry into the world of espionage, and will stop at nothing to terminate his involvement.  Despite their efforts, Bourne presses on to unravel the complicated puzzle that is key to who he is, and does so not only with resolve, but also with a moral conscience.This is James Bond style espionage, but with less womanizing and more realism, both on the level of characters and action sequences.  Rated PG-13 for a handful of profanities/blasphemy but primarily because of the violence, which is intense at times but rarely feels gratuitous, the cinematographic style adopted by the director usually makes us share in the post-combat exhaustion rather than exhilaration (although as with the Bourne Supremacy, there are times where the shakiness is excessive).  The story is gripping, arguably even more so than the previous film, and for the most part matches the appeal of the first of the series.  Bourne's techniques favour quick thinking rather than excess weaponry, and his ways of overcoming the bad guys even are touched with warm humor on occasion.  He's no cold-blooded killer, but a man with a growing conscience that we can empathize with more and more, motivated more by remorse and restraint than revenge.In the final analysis, The Bourne Ultimatum is a ripping good suspense adventure that will keep your heart pumping from start to finish! - GODLY GADFLY

reviewText: Paul Greengrass has stepped into the director's shoes for this third installment of the Jason Bourne identity crisis and in doing so has created nearly two hours of tension that would make Robert Ludlum proud! This is an example of how Hollywood can shine when it integrates all of the components of an 'action suspense thriller' by capitalizing on finding the best contributors available - actors, producers, cameramen, stunt men, script (Tony Gilroy, George Nolfi and Scott Z. Burns), composer of music (John Powell), editors - everyone of the hundreds required to pull off this superlative film. It is as fine as any thriller can be and reflects the intensity of concentration and understatement and respect for the viewers' intellect that crowned his excellent UNITED 93 and THE BOURNE SUPREMACY. The result is a polished movie that remains compelling form the opening frame to the final credits.For those who have read or watched Ludlum's Bourne trilogy the story line is at core very simple: Jason Bourne has lost his memory and struggles through terrifying confrontations with all governments and potential assassins, endures relentless chases, and defies the machinations of the world's intelligence sources to discover his true identity. The rest of the novels and films are the how.Matt Damon has come into his own as an electrifying screen presence as Jason Bourne: his acting is keen and his ability to hold our concern through impossible situations would be difficult to duplicate by other actors of this genre. The supporting cast includes such superb actors as Joan Allen, David Strathairn, Scott Glenn, Albert Finney, Paddy Considine, Daniel Brühl, Joey Ansah and a very large cast of others. The pacing and use of Intelligence techniques is extraordinary and is beautifully captured by the cinematography of DP Oliver Wood and finessed by the editing of Christopher Rouse.One aspect of this film that is the most frightening is to observe just how invasive the Intelligence portions of our government can be: there seemingly are no secrets about even the most personal aspects of our lives that cannot be flashed on multiscreens in the war room of the CIA and associated organizations. Perhaps this film will be a red flag to alert public attention as to how our right to privacy has been so visibly raped by the government in the name of security - a factor that makes watching this excellent movie even more terrifying! Grady Harp, November 07
summary: A Breathless, Intelligent, Finely Honed Part 3 of the Bourne Series

And while they may or may not scratch easier?, that has nothing to do with their compatability in the Blu-ray players. Case in point - AVATAR Blu-ray. Almost 50% of the Blu-ray players out in circulation could not play the Avatar Blu-ray disk. And even with firmware upgrades, many still could not play it properly without menus popping up or staying on screen, skipping, pausing and so on. One of the players that had the biggest problem with playing Avatar - Samsung. Samsung initially took more calls and complaints than any other manufacturer, and I'm not sure if they ever got the problem solved. I'm not bashing Samsung, both of my higher end Blu-ray players, the Marantz and the Pioneer couldn't play Avatar either, while my Magnavox (first generation) Blu-ray player played Avatar perfectly, with no problems, and no firmware upgrade. The point is, the Bourne flip-disks are fine, if you have the right player. (Probably Sony(not sure about PS3), Vizio, Panasonic, Magnavox/Insignia/Sylvania, just guessing). reviewText: I read in an online interview that, while Matt Damon hasn't entirely ruled out filming a fourth Bourne installment, he's put the kibosh on doing one in the immediate future. If he does end up not doing any more, this franchise goes out on a very high note. The Bourne movies have been consistently graced with intelligent scripts, diligent acting, and peerless production values. Oh, and nonstop adrenalin rushes. With THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, this series reaches its crescendo.The movie picks up with an injured Jason Bourne (Matt Damon) still being pursued in Moscow, Russia, where the prior film,The Bourne Supremacy (Widescreen Edition), ended. Bourne, of course, easily handles his predicament. The focus then shifts to a London journalist who's gotten a sniff of a potential headliner. Soon, his newspaper The Guardian is outing a front page story involving our amnesiac superspy, which naturally draws the eye of Bourne. The article also doesn't sit well with various clandestine government agencies (the CIA and the NSA). Specifically, one unhappy intelligence officer is Noah Vosen (David Strathairn), who ramrods Blackbriar, the hush hush CIA black ops program ressurected from the ashes of Treadstone. Treadstone being the original project which trained and programmed assassins, of which Bourne was the primary guinea pig. Naturally, the paranoid Vosen wants to, once and for all, eliminate Bourne, who is the mother of all loose ends. But Jason Bourne, too, has had enough. After running for three years, he wants all the answers regarding his past. And he wants it now.THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM keeps you rapt in your seat with two hours of intricate and well choreographed entertainment. The film's got smarts and forces the viewer to constantly pay attention as it doesn't linger too much on any reveals. And when things get revved up and Jason goes into action mode, the jittery hand-held cameras evoke an atmosphere of immediacy, of things barely kept in check, even though we assume that Bourne knows exactly what he's doing. There are screaming car chases here and extended rooftop pursuits and plenty of frenetic scenes with Bourne outthinking, outrunning, and, when it comes to it, just plain outslugging the foot soldiers of his near omnipresent and overwhelmingly equipped opponents. Nothing cute about his fights, either. His one-on-one, life or death struggle with the assassin in Morocco takes your breath away with its speed and primal brutality. No posing or James Bond witticisms here as it's made clear that the only objective is to take the other guy out, promptly and without any wasted moves. However, my favorite scene in the film takes place in Waterloo Station as Bourne aids a targeted reporter and attempts to talk him thru to safety via cell phone. Never has a sequence put more of an exclamation point on just how resourceful this guy is and how fast on his feet he thinks.Our government agencies once more come under scrutiny. Again, we are reminded of the immensity and scope of the power and tools at their hands, and of how easily such things can be misused. It boggles my mind that any cell phone conversation you may have can be accessed and recorded for posterity, and your every little secret can be ferreted out just as offhandedly. In the parlance of these covert agencies, a mundane statement such as "Let's activate the asset" carries grim connotations. The film presents these assets - apparently, the new euphemism for assassins - as unthinking automatons who linger in their hotel rooms as they await their next target. You get a feeling that, until they do receive their next assignment, there in their hotels they stay. On the other hand, Jason Bourne, who's strayed from his programming, has come to display clear remorse. In one evocative scene, as he gazes at his bloodied knuckles, he breaks his silence by stating, "I can see the faces of everyone I've killed. I just don't know their names."The unassuming and formerly boyish-looking Matt Damon was 36 years old during the filming of this, and while he still looks unassuming, the boyishness has given way to more weathered lines on his face, which works to convey more weight to his character. Fortunately, there's enough warmth in Damon to keep his stoic and laconic super agent from becoming merely robotic and too impersonal for the audience. As he goes thru his memory loss, performs his amazing feats, and takes a lickin' but keeps on tickin', one can sense the internal conflict going on. Matt Damon has never been known for his loquaciousness, and his natural reserve and everyday guy demeanor serve him well in this role.He's backed ably by a cast of veteran actors. As the main villain, David Strathairn nicely personifies the burueacratic mentality of Bourne's adversaries. It's not personal with these bad guys, they're just trying to clear out some red tape. Meanwhile, Scott Glenn has such a minimal role that I'm ambivalent about his performance. Returning to the fold are the very good Joan Allen as the agent with principles, Pamela Landy, and lovely Julia Stiles, who gets an expanded part as Nicky Parsons. A prior history with Bourne, possibly a personal one, is hinted at by Stiles' character, so it's unfortunate that their story arc seems to sputter out.With the cast and crew trotting the globe as they film on location in Moscow, Paris, Madrid, London, Tangier, and New York, it's no wonder Matt Damon wants to take a break. But it's all been worth it, to have had this wonderful capper in the trilogy. Finally, we learn of Jason Bourne's true identity. Of course, if you've read Robert Ludlum's novels, you would've been privy to it by now. But never mind. After all that Jason Bourne went thru, I feel good for him as he finally sees thru the muddle and gets a sense of closure. And, going by the raucous audience reaction at the final moments played out on the screen, I wouldn't count out another sequel. But, hopefully, Mattie's in it.

reviewText: Definitely the best of the franchise. Due to the story elements, this film operates on a different level than the first two, but it all works out. Ultimatum finds Bourne still suffering from his wounds that were inflicted at the end of Supremacy, desperate to get out of Moscow. He is determined to put an end to the agency's search for him. Within the agency, we meet Noah Vosen, the new head of the still ongoing search for Bourne. He reports directly to the CIA director, Ezra Kramer. Vosen proves to be nowhere near Bourne's capabilities, so he calls in Pamela Landy, introduced in Supremacy, to help him out. Much like she did with Brian Cox's character Abbott in Supremacy, she begins to grow suspicious of why the agency really wants Bourne and if he might actually be innocent. To further complicate things, there is a reporter in London who has some very interesting information on Bourne's past, but also has a very mysterious source that might be directly involved with the whole thing. And, of course, Bourne has begun having more visions. Like before, they are just brief flashes of scenes from his his past, along with voices and faces he doesn't recognize. In his quest to figure all this out, Bourne travels from Moscow, to Naples, to Madrid, to Tangiers, and finally, to New York City. This is where the final scene from Supremacy comes into play. It is seamlessly integrated into Ultimatum's storyline. Bourne meets up with Nicky Parsons, a former agency employee that is now willing to help him. She sees something in Bourne, much like what Marie saw in him. She begins to realize that he might very well be innocent, and that the agency is trying to eliminate an innocent man. This relationship between them is not at all romantic, but is very important. Bourne sees Nicky as someone that he can just use at first, but later, he realizes that she genuinely wants to help. Therefore, he has to protect her just because she didn't tell on him. Nicky sees Bourne as a highly tortured and emotionally conflicted person. I think that she has also had enough of the agency, and wants to do whatever she can. All throughout the film, we are treated to spectacular chases, fights, and some terrific acting by the entire cast. All of which has become expected from these films, and never gets old. Due to the agency's continued search and the inclusion of the reporter/source subplot, a lot of the film is spent away from Bourne. But this actually works in Bourne/Damon's favor, because literally everything that is happening is always focused on Bourne and what he is doing. Each member of the cast realizes and fully understands their role, and how their character ties in with the script. It is a great film because it ratchets up the intensity and suspense from the first two, without being overbearing or too simplistic.
summary: Wraps up Bourne's story in the best way possible.

reviewText: Oh how *subtle.* While rogue CIA director Ezra Kramer is plotting to murder Americans and use Pamela Landy as the fall gal, the director sticks an American flag on Kramer's desk.  That's subtlety in American cinema right there pal.  And if visual depiction of contempt for American patriotism isn't enough, how about the stock "the-rogue-CIA-is-out-to-kill-you" plot?  If you want better movies using that now-overworked anti-American plot, look no further than the much better done "Three Days of the Condor" or even "Clear and Present Danger."Kyle Smith, film critic for the New York Post, takes a similar, but more left-right theme in his review (humorously titled "When Liberals Attack"):"Bourne himself resolves the great contradiction bedeviling the liberal action movie --namely, how do you make your hero a killing machine .  .  .  without making him politically incorrect and illiberal along the way?  The ingenious solution is to make Bourne an unwilling killing machine, a man whose body is a weapon that his amnesia-ridden mind doesn't understand, or even quite control... Scenes of a captive Bourne being hooded and waterboarded in intentionally dehumanizing training sessions also tickle one of the left's most accessible pleasure centers, the one marked Gitmo guilt."LOL.  I wish I could write prose as good as Mr. Smith's.Besides the problem mentioned above, I must also reiterate the same problem I had with "Bourne Identity": the premise of the books was Jason Bourne as a good guy who lost his memory, not an amoral assassin who lost his memory after being subjected to brainwashing like something straight out of "Blood Diamond."Look, I appreciate Julia Stiles coming back.  That was good.  A little coincidental, but good.  However, that, and great star power, and lots of explosions, and good chase scenes, and exotic locales, just don't make up for this movie that at its heart doesn't like, want or care about your country.**  Of course, if you're not American, you'll probably love this film, since it both confirms and panders to your fears, stereotypes and prejudices about the U.S. Perhaps the film's political bias is simple recognition that overseas revenues constitute an important part of its total gross.
summary: Just too anti-American to be Bourne

reviewText: The Bourne Ultimatum may bring a close to the Bourne movies.  As one of the series, it is a great movie.  As a closer, it still leaves too much to be desired.This installment is very rushed and at times I had a feeling things were being left out for the sake of time.  However, it is still a great ride, with amazing special effects and fight scenes.  The only real downer for me is the crazy camera work.Bourne remembers more about who he is now and where he came from and succeeds in taking his fight to those made him into what he is. reviewText: I'll be perfectly honest; I don't think this franchise needed a third act.  I feel like Supremacy had already left the character in an intruiging position.  He had redeemed himself in the eyes of his former handlers, righted some wrongs, avenged his lost loved one, and despite STRONG adversity, demonstrated once and for all that he was a better person than his adversaries.  Besides that, he now knew his real name and by all appearances, was now free to finally, patiently take a look at his past and maybe visit his old high school or something.  So if, for some irrational reason, the producers felt compelled to make another sequel, atleast the character no longer needed to be portrayed as one man against the evil CIA/Military Industrial Complex.  He could go in another, less violent, equally interesting direction.  So when I heard they were going to make the inevitable threequel, that's the direction I assumed the filmmakers were going to go in.  But instead, what we got is another hour and a half of Jason Bourne very skillfully kicking the crap out've nearly everybody with US government security clearance, this time, so he can reveal to the world how evil the framers of Treadstone really are.  Meh.  The thing is, it was mostly all done before.On the plus side, the action is extremely well choreographed, the stunts are frigging amazing, and plot holes aside, this film avoids the vast majority of pitfalls that make most second sequels completely suck.  The movie also looks very good and the color scheme is more akin to the first Bourne movie than the second one, which used more grimy colors.  So in that sense, the film was more enjoyable for this reviewer.  And Matt Damon and the rest of the cast give consistent, generally engaging performances.But the thing is, that's about all there is going for it.  Ultimately, the movie just leaves the character where he appeared to be at the end of the last one.  And while it resembles Identity a little more than its direct predecessor, it lacks the innocent, hip charm that Doug Liman seemed to infuse into the first film.  Much like the original's score, the story for that film was less consistent and while everyone else on Earth seems to consider that a shortcoming, this reviewer disagrees by arguing that that reflected the pacing of real life more authentically, making it feel much more accessible to an average nobody who can still appreciate how intimidating the big bad world can be.  Paralleling this, Jason Bourne is no longer the bewildered-looking guy who could pass as your innocent college professor.  He's, as one reviewer deftly put it, "an SAS-ninja-jedi," who we know probably won't die.  Or will he...? :-)So in summary, see this movie if you like good acting and enjoy above-averagedly intelligent entries in the spy genre.  But you may be a little dissapointed if you're expecting a revelation about the Bourne character.

reviewText: I hate to see the ending of one of the best action series of recent times because apparently Matt Damon is not coming back for another movie--I don't blame him, he doesn't want to get stereotyped. It was a great ride and I hate to see its culmination. Director of the last two series Paul Greengrass, once again gives us plenty of action sequences with raw power and stylish cinematography, but also we finally get to see the true origins of our main character. He is a present-day James Bond who went rogue to a corrupt organization that created him but betrayed him in the end. The Bourne Ultimatum is on my list of this year's best.Brief Intro Story:After surviving a certain death in Moscow, the wounded Jason Bourne (Matt Damon) is still in Europe taking care of some business. He makes a stop to tell Marie's brother (Bourne's girl in the second film) that his sister is dead. Bourne really loved her and wanted to give up his past and start a new life, but her death changed all that.As he is reading a newspaper, Bourne finds out that a British journalist Simon Ross (Paddy Considine) has written an article about him and knows about operation "Blackbriar." Apparently he knows something about Bourne's origin. He travels to London and finally contacts Simon, but he gets killed by a sniper who follows orders for a small CIA secret team led by the evil Noah Vosen (David Strathairn). Mysteriously Vosen wants him dead fast and he will use all the CIA's resources to do so. Deputy Director Pamela Landy (Joan Allen) thinks it's not a good idea to kill Bourne--she prefers to keep him alive. Meanwhile Bourne is following more clues that the journalist left behind. He is getting closer to the truth, but it won't be easy. The CIA's killers are after him.Review:In this last installment of The Bourne Ultimatum, we get to know Bourne's origins and why he has vivid nightmares and visions of his past. We also like the character's perseverance to get to the bottom of all this animosity towards him--the reasons why different agencies what to kill him and who he really is. He is strong, intelligent, determined, and ready to even risk his own life in order to find the truth. I always have a special admiration for this character and fans of the series will be pleased by the character's coolness and cleverness to be a step ahead of his enemies. But he also makes new friends in this movie from the organization that betrayed him--this creates drama and a sense of humanity of our main character.Academy Award Winner Paul Greengrass (United 93) knows how to make an action film, pure and simple--his camerawork is stylish and always puts you right in the action. The filmmaker takes us around the world--a total of three continents--following our main character's search for the truth. We also get to see state-of-the-art espionage technology used by agencies like the CIA that really makes us think about our own security, but this doesn't work for Bourne who makes a fool out of the CIA. The car chase extravaganza in this film is entertaining, raw and dynamic, perhaps the best of the year--it's full of difficult stunts that will keep you on the edge of your seat. When it comes to martial arts, Bourne has no match. The fight sequences are extremely raw; Bourne's moves are fast and powerful--similar to the Israeli Krav Maga fighting style.The Verdict:With an excellent cast, great action sequences and the satisfying ending, The Bourne Ultimatum will not disappoint fans of stylish action films. I'm sorry James Bond, but you have to step aside. Director Paul Greengrass is once again, the star--besides Damon--of one of the best action pack of the year because of his style to make new cutting-edge films. I hope Damon reconsiders and make another movie. I truly hope so.

reviewText: Bourne Ultimatum (movie #3) is similar to Bourne Identity (movie #1) in that it exists simply for the sake of the action. There's hardly any literary content at all. It's just a straightforward plot that moves the action along. It's like so many other action movies. Sure the production is impressive with explosions, stunts, car chases, fighting, etc, but as far as dialog, motivations, characters, plot twists, or anything else clever, that's all been carefully stripped out. That doesn't cut it for me and I rate this movie low. I like the Bourne Supremacy (movie #2) the best. That one has more story.Other reviewers here agree with me on the above points, but I disagree with them on the excellence of the action. I don't think it's all that great as I'll explain below along with my low opinions on the lack of story. I agree with another reviewer here that my review on the literary merit of the movie is a waste of time. The movie is about action and that's it. Critiquing its literary merits is like critiquing the safeness of a motorcycle. It's simply not about that.Anyway....The girl in this movie hardly speaks at all. She just walks around looking dumb and worried. If the girl was paid by the line, they paid her about $50 for her "role." Her close-ups become comical because repeatedly they cut to her, she looks worriedly into the camera, and then doesn't speak.As many others have pointed out, the shaky camera work is annoying/nauseating/amateurish direction. I really hated it and it really did make me sick.The story has a long, straightforward build up to an ultra-lame, straightforward conclusion, which makes me feel like I wasted my time. What's the big deal about his training anyway...you just need to train him as a sniper, which is no big deal, and then you're done. What Jason does is not that different than any other soldier, especially a sniper. Much more interesting was Bridget Fonda in "Point of No Return" and her cycle of training, initiation, and wanting out.Again in the "unintentionally funny" department, we get comedy/spoof/"so bad it's funny" like running commentary:"He's looking right at her!""He drove off the roof!"As if we, the audience, couldn't see that he just drove off the roof. Actually this comedy material was some of the best fun this movie has to offer.Jason takes the unneeded/indefensible risk of calling the CIA security down on him before he even cracks the safe. No trained burglar would do that. He just needed to hang up the phone as soon as the guy answered and said his name. And if cracking the safe was that easy the CIA wouldn't be using that safe. How did Jason know that the spook used his name as the safe voice password? He could have used any phrase. Ludicrous.During the chase where the assassin chases the girl, Jason repeatedly jumps through the windows. Once is enough, twice is repetitious, thrice is an eye roll. He did it, like, six times. Severe lack of imagination on the part of the movie makers. Plus, that assassin must be a super blood hound to be able to track the girl from the street as she runs around on the rooftops.Grade: Waste of time.

reviewText: Paul Greengrass who got a Best Director Oscar nomination for "United 93" in 2006 helmed this project.  The hand-held camera in the action sequences magnified the sense of unease and chaos.  Matt Damon was nominated for Best Actor back in 1997 for "Good Will Hunting," when he came away with the Best Original Screenplay Oscar.  As Jason Bourne, he's tightly wound.  His characterizations vary slightly from what we've seen in films likeThe Departed (Widescreen Edition)& "The Good Shepherd."  Julia Stiles again plays Nicky Parsons with a tight-lipped poker face.  She does an excellent job as the sympathetic spy on the run.  David Starthairn who got an Oscar nomination for "Good Night & Good Luck" plays Noah Vosen, the ruthless CIA director who will break the law in order to protect it.  Scott Glenn who did a nice job opposite Hillary Swank in "Freedom Writers" plays Ezra Kramer, the big boss who is playing both sides.  Five-time Oscar nominee Albert Finney ("Tom Jones," "Murder on the Orient Express," "The Dresser," "Under the Volcano," & "Erin Brockovich") plays Dr. Albert Hirsch who recruited Bourne into the spy program and remade him into an assassin.  Joan Allen plays Pamela Landy, the agent who does not have an ulterior motive.  Allen smoked the screen for me inThe Upside of Angerwhich also earned her Best Actress awards from both the Chicago and San Diego Film Critics Associations.  She shows a complex character on a continual political balance wheel within her agency.  Joey Ansah does a great job as the assassin Desh who flies around Morocco on a motorcycle.  The Film won Oscars for Best Editing (Christopher Rouse), Best Sound Editing (Per Hallbert & Karen Baker Landers), & Best Sound Mixing (Kirk A. Francis, Scott Millaw & David Parker).  "The Bourne Ultimatum" is an excellent film that picked me up at first frame and deposited me breathlessly at the closing credits.  Bravo!

reviewText: Watching this on the big screen, I felt as though they took everything that was good in the first two movies, and mashed them up hoping it would work again.We all know that the Bourne films give us action sequences like we've never seen before. Here, that trend repeats itself, with an amazing sequence filmed in Morocco where Matt Damon has to save Julia Stiles from a hitman.However, this is not so much a film, as it is an endless string of action vignettes all strung together. One after the other they come at you, and while any action fan is going to have fun watching this, it lacks the emotional depth and mystery that made the first two films such classics. Also, Franka Potente's absence is sorely felt in this film, as Julia Stiles is hardly a match for her.The story gets even more ludicrous - to the point that there is no actual story. At one point, you even had the 'bad guy' hide files named 'Top Secret' (in BOLD RED no less) in a safe and then he looks around to see if no one has observed him. Haven't we left this sort of dumb-as-nails 'suspense' back in the 1980s? I mean, come on, even certain Lifetime movies have more plot than this.So all we get is Matt Damon (in terrific physical shape, though I was surprised at how haggard his face had gotten in the last two years) jumping through glass windows, leaping from building to building - and every image you had of him being a street-smart spy is shattered, as he is reduced to some sort of mega superhero who just WON'T DIE no matter what accident. Toward the end he is involved in a horrific car crash that should have crushed his body, but he just gets up and walks away. I do subscribe to the 'suspension of belief' theory, but this was taking things too far, honestly.The script is very weak. Obvious things are shouted out every now and then, for example - 'Oh My GOD, hes looking at us from across the street!', and 'Oh My GOD, he just drove off the bridge!', like some sort of absurd commentary when we know exactly what happened. I felt this was made for a ten year old rather than for all audiences.This is not to say that the film is bad. On the contrary, the action is always excellent, but I think that this was a terrible way to end the trilogy, especially when the second film in particular had a very strong plot, great emoting, and superb dialog. Here, its just one car chase after another, or one murder attempt to outdo the previous one, and I just felt that director had totally lost all respect for the audience.Three Stars. A very average film. Oh, and an hour after you've watched it, you won't even remember half of it, its that forgettable.
